title: Trump’s $300 Million SPAC Deal May Have Skirted Securities Laws
content: The former president began discussing a deal with a ‘blank check’ company early this year. Investors weren’t told.

more_info.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Lauren Hirsch and David Enrich

title: What if It Never Gets Easier to Be a Working Parent?
content: The shock of the pandemic threw care taking arrangements into disarray. Many families find themselves back in the same precarious arrangement they had before, with the burden still on mothers.

title: U.S. Agrees to Roll Back European Steel and Aluminum Tariffs
content: The deal, which comes as U.S. and E.U. allies meet in Rome, will keep some trade protections in place in a nod to metalworking unions that supported President Biden.

more_info.byline: By Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers

title: Union for John Deere Workers Reaches Tentative Deal to End 2-Week Strike
content: The agreement must still be approved by U.A.W. members. They had rejected an earlier accord negotiated by the union.

title: How the Supply Chain Stole Halloween
content: Good luck trying to find a meme-inspired costume, or any costume at all.

title: A Major Persian Gulf Oil Producer Tries to Burnish Its Climate Credentials
content: Trying to attract investors and retain customers, the United Arab Emirates says it will step up its efforts to cut emissions.

title: Women May Be Better Investors Than Men. Let Me Mansplain Why.
content: Overconfidence is bad, and women are less likely to fall victim to it.

title: Credit Card Debt Is Bad for More Than Just Your Finances
content: A new study says that worries about repaying debt may lead to poor health later in life. So here are some tips for dealing with your bills.

title: How Should Billionaires Be Taxed?
content: A proposed ‘billionaire tax’ appears to have been shelved, but questions about how to best tax extreme wealth remain.

title: Louise Slade, Scientist Who Studied the Molecules in Food, Dies at 74
content: Her research focused on how to keep dough, bread, cookies and crackers tasting delicious even after weeks on a grocery store shelf.

title: Pressure Grows on G20 Nations to Get Covid Vaccines to the Poor
content: The world’s leaders are focusing on preventing future pandemics, but experts say rich nations are not doing enough to help the poor survive the current one.

more_info.byline: By Katie Rogers, Jim Tankersley and Jason Horowitz

title: Biden Finds Raising Corporate Tax Rates Easier Abroad Than at Home
content: As the Group of 20 seals a new global minimum tax for companies, the president has scaled back his plans to tax U.S. corporations more.

org_facet: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

title: A Call of ‘Cold Gun!’ A Live Round. And Death on a Film Set.
content: A reconstruction of the events leading up to the fatal shooting of the cinematographer of “Rust,” the Alec Baldwin western, reveals a troubled production and a series of errors.

title: Has the Christmas Shopping Season Overtaken Halloween?
content: Retailers (and some celebrities) are getting into the holiday spirit super-early this year.

title: Rick Steves on the Return of Travel and Why It Matters
content: The travel writer and TV personality is back in Europe, planning itineraries for next year. Travel, he says, can help us understand the world. Here’s how he recommends doing it.

title: A Global Tax Deal Is at Hand. Here’s How It Would Work.
content: President Biden will sign on to an international pact aimed at ending profit-shifting by large companies. Here’s a look at what it means.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Got a Bit Meta in His Meta Presentation
content: For those watching closely, his 80-minute video announcing Facebook’s rebrand delivered some self-referential jokes.

title: 8 Companies That Changed Their Names to Signal a Strategy Shift
content: Facebook said on Thursday that it was rebranding as Meta, taking a step to distance itself from the controversies it faces. How has this corporate strategy worked for other companies?

more_info.byline: By Jenny Gross and Christine Hauser

title: Wall Street’s climb makes October the best month for stocks this year.
content: The S&P 500 rose nearly 7 percent for the month as strong earnings reports and progress toward a spending deal in Washington helped investors shake off a number of concerns.

title: When a Wheelchair Becomes a Magical Chariot
content: Seven families share their stories of putting together the perfect Halloween costumes for children with special needs.

title: Big Hires, Big Money and a D.C. Blitz: A Bold Plan to Dominate Crypto
content: The Silicon Valley firm Andreessen Horowitz, whose founders played big roles in the development of the internet, aims to own a huge part of the digital currency world — and set the rules for it, too.

title: Mimi Levin Lieber, 93, Dies; Her Focus Groups Shaped Postwar Marketing
content: She helped Fortune 500 companies sell to women in the 1960s and ’70s, then became a stalwart promoter of early childhood literacy.

title: The Truck Stops Here: A Shipping Broker on the Supply Chain Madness
content: He helps move things from point A to point B. And he thinks you should already be shopping for the holidays.

title: F.D.A. Clears First Coronavirus Vaccine for 5- to 11-Year-Olds

title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Has ‘No Idea’ How Live Rounds Got on Set, Lawyers Say
content: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed was in charge of firearms on the New Mexico film set where Alec Baldwin fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun that was not supposed to contain live ammunition.

title: An Arena Where the Goal Is ‘Net Zero’ Carbon Emissions, Even From Fans
content: The operators of Climate Pledge Arena, home to the N.H.L.’s newest team, the Seattle Kraken, plan to reduce and offset its entire planet-warming footprint. They still have a lot to prove.

title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron continue to report higher profits, helped by rising oil prices.
content: In the third quarter, the companies continued their rebound from the collapse in demand at the start of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Fed’s favorite inflation index remained at 30-year high as pay surged.
content: The Federal Reserve is closely watching inflation, and the numbers have been sharply elevated in recent months.

title: Politico’s journalists are seeking union recognition from its new owner.
content: The labor unit says it has also submitted to the National Labor Relations Board cards from more than 80 percent of eligible workers seeking to form a union.

title: The eurozone recovery continues, but inflation hits the highest in 13 years.
content: Economic output grew 2.2 percent in the third quarter as the region recovered from a double-dip recession, while inflation jumped to 4.1 percent.

title: Could a New Name Help Facebook After All?
content: There is evidence the change to Meta is more than window dressing.

title: Wooing Newcomers to ‘NASCAR Nation’
